headline.main: Eli Lilly and the Dangers of a Drug (5 Letters)
headline.print_headline: Eli Lilly and the Dangers of a Drug

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation is giving $47 million in grants for the control of neglected tropical diseases, now almost forgotten in wealthy nations, that still cause excruciating pain, disfigurement and disability for millions of the world's poorest people, the recipients announced yesterday. The grants are unusual in that they do not single out individual diseases. Instead, they aim to test the idea that diseases such as trachoma, river blindness, lymphatic filariasis and hookworm, which largely afflict the rural poor, can be tackled together more effectively and cheaply than one at a time.

headline.main: Gateses Give $47 Million to Bolster Coordinated Assaults on Diseases

docs.abstract: Bill and Mellinda Gates Foundation donates $47 million for control of neglected tropical diseases that cause pain, disfigurement and disability among millions of world's poorest people; Dr Regina Rabinovich explains effort to shift away from appeals for high-profile diseases and encourage efficiencies of treatment for scourges such as river blindness, trachoma and lymphatic filariasis (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Eli Lilly Said to Play Down Risk of Top Pill'' (front page, Dec. 17), about the company's decision to cover up health effects of its top-selling schizophrenia medication, Zyprexa, is a good example of the strong link between product safety and product liability. Lawsuits are often the only means for the public to learn about dangerous drugs. This is especially true today, as the Food and Drug Administration has proved unable to keep some unsafe drugs off the market.

headline.main: Eli Lilly and the Dangers of a Drug

docs.abstract: Five letters comment on Eli Lilly's marketing of schizophrenia medication Zyprexa (Dec 17 article and Dec 19 editorial); Joanne Doroshow, executive director, Center for Justice and Democracy, says that if lawsuits had not been brought, dangers of drug would not be known to wider public; Dr Marshal Mandelkern says Eli Lilly behaved as any for-profit corporation would and physicians must remain objective about drugs and not be financially entangled with drug or insurance companies; Pamela Spiro Wagner says Zyprexa was miracle antipsychotic for her; Barbara Fischkin says spector of autistic children using Zyprexa and gaining weight or developing diabetes is horrifying; David Berman says we need to get money-changers out of medicine and make drugs for people not for profit; drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: The warning was issued after two patients taking the cancer drug Rituxan as a treatment for the autoimmune disorder lupus died from a rare brain infection.

headline.main: Warning Given on Drug’s Use to Treat Lupus
headline.print_headline: Warning Given On Drug’s Use To Treat Lupus

docs.snippet: The warning was issued after two patients taking the cancer drug Rituxan as a treatment for the autoimmune disorder lupus died from a rare brain infection.

docs.lead_paragraph: Biogen Idec and Genentech have warned doctors of two deaths among patients receiving the cancer drug Rituxan as a treatment for the autoimmune disorder lupus. The medicine, used to treat patients with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and rheumatoid arthritis, is not approved as a therapy for lupus, Biogen, based in Cambridge, Mass., said yesterday in a regulatory filing. The patients developed a rare brain infection called progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, or P.M.L., the companies said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Jon S. Corzine announced yesterday that New Jersey would offer $7 million worth of grants for embryonic stem cell research, and $3 million for the less controversial area of adult stem-cell research. The grants, which double the amount given during last year's first-ever round of grants, are intended to augment the state's attempt to become one of the leading laboratories for such research, which supporters hope can eventually help find cures for diseases like Parkinson's, pediatric AIDS and sickle cell anemia. DAVID W. CHEN
